S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Accuracy on different threat models
S5.T1.table:
CIFAR-10 CIFAR-noniid
Attack FL SL Biscotti DeFL FL SL Biscotti DeFL
No 0.924 0.926 0.891 0.899 0.922 0.925 0.840 0.836
Gaussian (σ𝜎\sigma=0.03) 0.905 0.904 0.887 0.888 0.922 0.924 0.891 0.893
Gaussian (σ𝜎\sigma=1.00) 0.184 0.197 0.899 0.894 0.345 0.338 0.872 0.876
Sign-flipping (σ𝜎\sigma=-1.0) 0.837 0.843 0.880 0.885 0.799 0.803 0.888 0.883
Sign-flipping (σ𝜎\sigma=-2.0) 0.453 0.456 0.890 0.893 0.423 0.421 0.878 0.881
Sign-flipping (σ𝜎\sigma=-4.0) 0.126 0.136 0.896 0.893 0.164 0.175 0.866 0.873
Label-flipping 0.894 0.893 0.889 0.890 0.890 0.884 0.872 0.876
references: As mentioned in Section 3.1, we measure 3 types of poisoning attacks with different attack factors on 1 of 4 nodes. As shown in Table 1, FedAvg-based approaches (FL, SL) share similar accuracy while Multi-Krum-based approaches (Biscotti, DeFL) share similar accuracy. When there is no or a mild attack, i.e. Gaussian attack (σ𝜎\sigma=0.03) and label-flipping attack, the accuracy of FedAvg-based approaches is slightly higher than that of Multi-Krum-based ones. The reason is that Multi-Krum filters outlier weights that might be trained by honest nodes and are supposed to be aggregated. This is also why the accuracy of Multi-Krum-based approaches on CIFAR-noniid is lower than that of CIFAR-10. However, when there is a relatively severe attack, the accuracy of Multi-Krum-based approaches is significantly higher than that of FedAvg-based ones. This indicates that Multi-Krum effectively detects poisoned weights and aggregates with correct weights from honest nodes.

Attack FL SL Biscotti DeFL

references: We choose sign-flipping attack (σ𝜎\sigma=-2.0) on CIFAR-noniid to measure the accuracy under different Byzantine rates β𝛽\beta, as shown in Table 2. We scale DeFL on 4, 7, 10 nodes, and "a𝑎a+b𝑏b" means there are a𝑎a honest nodes and b𝑏b Byzantine node(s). As β𝛽\beta raises, the accuracy of FedAvg-based approaches drops dramatically, while the accuracy of Multi-Krum-based ones remains stable and significantly higher.

references: As mentioned in Section 3.1, we measure 3 types of poisoning attacks with different attack factors on 1 of 4 nodes. As shown in Table 3, FedAvg-based approaches (FL, SL) share similar accuracy while Multi-Krum-based approaches (Biscotti, DeFL) share similar accuracy. In most settings, especially when the attack is severe, the accuracy of Multi-Krum-based approaches is higher than that of FedAvg-based ones. This indicates that Multi-Krum effectively detects poisoned weights and aggregates with correct weights from honest nodes.

A1.T4.table:
Attack FL SL Biscotti DeFL

3+1 (β𝛽\beta=0.25) 0.537 0.539 0.700 0.699
7+0 (β𝛽\beta=0.00) 0.701 0.700 0.700 0.701

references: We choose Gaussian attack (σ𝜎\sigma=1.00) on Sentiment-noniid to measure the accuracy under different Byzantine rates β𝛽\beta, as shown in Table 4. We scale DeFL on 4, 7, 10 nodes, and "a𝑎a+b𝑏b" means there are a𝑎a honest nodes and b𝑏b Byzantine node(s). When the number of nodes is fixed, as β𝛽\beta raises, the accuracy of FedAvg-based approaches drops dramatically, while the accuracy of Multi-Krum-based ones remains stable and significantly higher. Besides, when β𝛽\beta keeps stable or even slightly raises, as the number of nodes increases, the accuracy of FedAvg-based approaches raises. The reason could be that the higher ensemble property of more nodes contributes to better generalizability and robustness, however, it is beyond the scope of this paper.
